previewConcepts.example: Make shapes with sides and corners

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Shape Station. I see windows on the walls. The windows have different shapes. I look at the sides and corners.
pages.mathConcept: Shapes have sides and corners we can count
pages.mathTip: Look carefully at the sides. Then count the corners.

pages.question: What parts of shapes do we look at?
pages.mathContext: I see windows on the walls. The windows have different shapes. I look at the sides and corners.
pages.mathHint: Read the last sentence. What two things do I look at?
pages.successMessage: Yes! We look at sides and corners.

pages.sentence: I see a square window. I count the sides. There are 4 sides. I count the corners. There are 4 corners. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A square has 4 equal sides and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: Touch each side as you count. Then touch each corner.

pages.question: How many sides does a square have?
pages.mathContext: I see a square window. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the sides of the square. Touch each one.
pages.successMessage: Great! A square has 4 sides.

pages.sentence: I see a triangle sign on the wall. I count the sides. There are 3 sides. I count the corners. There are 3 corners. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners
pages.mathTip: Count each side. Then count each corner.

pages.question: How many corners does a triangle have?
pages.mathContext: I see a triangle sign on the wall. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the corners of the triangle. Point to each one.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A triangle has 3 corners.

pages.menuStory: The snack cart has treats. Each snack is a different shape. What will you choose?

pages.sentence: I see a rectangle tile on the floor. I count the sides. There are 4 sides. I count the corners. There are 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: A rectangle is like a square but longer on two sides.

pages.question: Which shape has 3 sides?
pages.mathContext: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners. A square has 4 sides and 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Think about each shape. Which one has 3 sides?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A triangle has 3 sides.

pages.question: I want to build a shape with 4 corners. Which shape should I build?
pages.mathContext: A triangle has 3 corners. A square has 4 corners. A rectangle has 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count how many corners each shape has. Which ones have 4?
pages.successMessage: Great! A square has 4 corners.

pages.question: How many sides does a rectangle have?
pages.mathContext: I see a rectangle tile on the floor. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners.
pages.mathHint: Count the sides of the rectangle. Go around all the edges.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A rectangle has 4 sides.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Food Court. I see many foods. Each food has a shape. I can make 2D shapes. 2D shapes are flat.
pages.mathConcept: 2D shapes are flat shapes like circles, squares, and triangles
pages.mathTip: 2D means flat. You can draw 2D shapes on paper.

pages.question: What does 2D mean?
pages.mathContext: I can make 2D shapes. 2D shapes are flat.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What word describes 2D shapes?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 2D shapes are flat.

pages.sentence: I see a pizza. The pizza is a circle. A circle is round. It has no sides and no corners. The pizza is a flat circle.
pages.mathConcept: A circle is round with no sides and no corners
pages.mathTip: A circle is round all the way around. No sides. No corners.

pages.question: What shape is the pizza?
pages.mathContext: I see a pizza. The pizza is a circle.
pages.mathHint: Read about the pizza. What shape is it?
pages.successMessage: Great! The pizza is a circle.

pages.sentence: I see a sandwich. The sandwich is a rectangle. A rectangle has 4 sides and 4 corners. Two sides are long. Two sides are short.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangle has 4 sides (2 long, 2 short) and 4 corners
pages.mathTip: In a rectangle, opposite sides are the same length.

pages.question: What shape is the sandwich?
pages.mathContext: I see a sandwich. The sandwich is a rectangle.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentences. Find the shape of the sandwich.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The sandwich is a rectangle.

pages.sentence: I see a rice ball. The rice ball is a triangle. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners. All the sides make a triangle shape.
pages.mathConcept: A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners
pages.mathTip: Count the sides of a triangle. Then count the corners.

pages.menuStory: The food court has many foods. Each one is a different shape. What will you eat?

pages.question: How many sides does the rice ball have?
pages.mathContext: I see a rice ball. The rice ball is a triangle. A triangle has 3 sides and 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: A triangle has how many sides? Count them.
pages.successMessage: Nice! A triangle has 3 sides.

pages.sentence: I see a cheese slice. The cheese slice is a trapezoid. A trapezoid has 4 sides and 4 corners. The sides are different lengths.
pages.mathConcept: A trapezoid has 4 sides of different lengths
pages.mathTip: A trapezoid has 4 sides, but they are not all the same length.

pages.question: Which food is a circle?
pages.mathContext: The pizza is a circle. The sandwich is a rectangle. The rice ball is a triangle.
pages.mathHint: Think about which food is round. Circles are round.
pages.successMessage: Great! The pizza is a circle.

pages.question: I want to make a square. How many sides do I need?
pages.mathContext: A square has 4 sides and 4 corners. All sides are the same length.
pages.mathHint: Think about a square. Count the sides.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A square has 4 sides.

pages.question: Which shape has no corners?
pages.mathContext: A circle is round. It has no sides and no corners. A square has 4 corners. A triangle has 3 corners.
pages.mathHint: Think about each shape. Which one has no corners at all?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A circle has no corners.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Drink Station. I see many drinks. The drinks come in 3D shapes. 3D shapes are solid. They are not flat.
pages.mathConcept: 3D shapes are solid shapes that are not flat
pages.mathTip: 3D means solid. You can hold 3D shapes in your hand.

pages.question: What does 3D mean?
pages.mathContext: The drinks come in 3D shapes. 3D shapes are solid. They are not flat.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What word describes 3D shapes?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 3D shapes are solid.

pages.sentence: I see a juice box. The juice box is a rectangular prism. It has 6 flat faces. It has 12 edges. It looks like a box.
pages.mathConcept: A rectangular prism has 6 faces and 12 edges
pages.mathTip: A rectangular prism is like a box. Count the flat sides.

pages.question: What shape is the juice box?
pages.mathContext: I see a juice box. The juice box is a rectangular prism.
pages.mathHint: Read about the juice box. What is its shape?
pages.successMessage: Great! The juice box is a rectangular prism.

pages.sentence: I see a soda can. The soda can is a cylinder. It has 2 flat faces on the top and bottom. It has 1 curved edge. It can roll.
pages.mathConcept: A cylinder has 2 flat circular faces and 1 curved surface
pages.mathTip: A cylinder can roll. It has circles on the ends.

pages.question: What shape is the soda can?
pages.mathContext: I see a soda can. The soda can is a cylinder.
pages.mathHint: Read about the soda can. Find its shape.
pages.successMessage: Yes! The soda can is a cylinder.

pages.menuStory: The drink station has many choices. Each drink has a different shape. What will you choose?

pages.sentence: I see an ice cream cone. The ice cream cone is a cone. It has 1 flat face on the bottom. It has 1 point at the top. It cannot roll.
pages.mathConcept: A cone has 1 flat circular face and 1 point
pages.mathTip: A cone has a point. It has a circle at the bottom.

pages.question: What shape is the ice cream cone?
pages.mathContext: I see an ice cream cone. The ice cream cone is a cone.
pages.mathHint: Read about the ice cream. What shape is it?
pages.successMessage: Nice! The ice cream cone is a cone.

pages.sentence: I see ice cubes in my drink. Each ice cube is a cube. A cube has 6 square faces. All the faces are the same size.
pages.mathConcept: A cube has 6 equal square faces
pages.mathTip: A cube is like a box. All sides are squares. All sides are equal.

pages.question: How many faces does a cube have?
pages.mathContext: I see ice cubes in my drink. A cube has 6 square faces.
pages.mathHint: Count the faces of a cube. How many are there?
pages.successMessage: Great! A cube has 6 faces.

pages.question: Which shape can roll?
pages.mathContext: A cylinder can roll. A cone has a point and cannot roll. A cube has flat faces.
pages.mathHint: Think about which shapes are round. Round shapes can roll.
pages.successMessage: Yes! A cylinder can roll.

pages.question: Which shape has a point at the top?
pages.mathContext: A cone has 1 point at the top. A cylinder has flat ends. A cube has square faces.
pages.mathHint: Think about the shapes. Which one comes to a point?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A cone has a point at the top.

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Tile Workshop. I see many tiles. The tiles are different shapes. I can put shapes together to make new shapes.
pages.mathConcept: We can combine shapes to create new, bigger shapes
pages.mathTip: When you put shapes together, you can make a new shape.

pages.question: What can I do with shapes?
pages.mathContext: I see many tiles. The tiles are different shapes. I can put shapes together to make new shapes.
pages.mathHint: Read the last sentence. What can I do?
pages.successMessage: Yes! You can put shapes together.

pages.sentence: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square. I made a new shape from two shapes.
pages.mathConcept: Two triangles can combine to make a square
pages.mathTip: When you put two right triangles together, they can make a square.

pages.question: What shape do two triangles make?
pages.mathContext: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square.
pages.mathHint: Read about the two triangles. What do they make?
pages.successMessage: Great! Two triangles make a square.

pages.sentence: I take two squares. I put them side by side. The two squares make a rectangle. The rectangle is longer than one square.
pages.mathConcept: Two squares side by side make a rectangle
pages.mathTip: When you put squares next to each other, you make a rectangle.

pages.question: What do two squares make when you put them side by side?
pages.mathContext: I take two squares. I put them side by side. The two squares make a rectangle.
pages.mathHint: Read the sentence. What shape do two squares make?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Two squares make a rectangle.

pages.menuStory: The workshop has many tile projects. Each one uses different shapes. What will you build?

pages.sentence: I make a big triangle. I use three small triangles. I put them together carefully. Now I have one big triangle made from three small triangles.
pages.mathConcept: Smaller shapes can combine to make larger shapes of the same type
pages.mathTip: You can use small shapes to build bigger shapes.

pages.question: How many small triangles did I use?
pages.mathContext: I make a big triangle. I use three small triangles. Now I have one big triangle made from three small triangles.
pages.mathHint: Count how many small triangles I used.
pages.successMessage: Nice! You used 3 small triangles.

pages.question: I want to make a rectangle. Which shapes can I use?
pages.mathContext: Two squares make a rectangle. Two triangles can make a square. Shapes can combine to make new shapes.
pages.mathHint: Think about what shapes combine to make a rectangle.
pages.successMessage: Great! Two squares make a rectangle.

pages.question: What new shape can two triangles make?
pages.mathContext: I take two triangles. I put them together. The two triangles make a square.
pages.mathHint: Remember what happened when we put two triangles together.
pages.successMessage: Yes! Two triangles can make a square.

pages.question: I have 4 small squares. I put them in a 2 by 2 pattern. What shape do I make?
pages.mathContext: Small squares can combine to make bigger shapes. When you put 4 squares in a square pattern, you make a bigger square.
pages.mathHint: Think about 4 squares in a square pattern. What big shape do they make?
pages.successMessage: Nice! 4 small squares make a big square.

previewConcepts.example: Cut a pizza into 2 equal parts
Cut a pizza into 4 equal parts
All pieces are the same size

pages.sentence: I arrive at the Pizza Party. I see pizzas and sandwiches. I need to share the food fairly. I will cut the food into equal parts.
pages.mathConcept: Fair sharing means cutting into equal parts
pages.mathTip: Equal parts means all the pieces are the same size.

pages.question: What does equal parts mean?
pages.mathContext: I need to share the food fairly. I will cut the food into equal parts.
pages.mathHint: Read about equal parts. What does it mean?
pages.successMessage: Yes! Equal parts are the same size.

pages.sentence: I cut a pizza into 2 equal parts. Each part is called a half. There are 2 halves. The 2 halves make 1 whole pizza.
pages.mathConcept: A half is 1 of 2 equal parts
pages.mathTip: When you cut something into 2 equal parts, each part is a half.

pages.question: How many halves are in 1 whole pizza?
pages.mathContext: I cut a pizza into 2 equal parts. There are 2 halves. The 2 halves make 1 whole pizza.
pages.mathHint: Count the halves. How many equal parts?
pages.successMessage: Great! There are 2 halves in 1 whole.

pages.sentence: I cut a sandwich into 4 equal parts. Each part is called a fourth. Each part is also called a quarter. There are 4 fourths. The 4 fourths make 1 whole sandwich.
pages.mathConcept: A fourth or quarter is 1 of 4 equal parts
pages.mathTip: When you cut into 4 equal parts, each part is a fourth or a quarter.

pages.question: How many fourths are in 1 whole sandwich?
pages.mathContext: I cut a sandwich into 4 equal parts. There are 4 fourths. The 4 fourths make 1 whole sandwich.
pages.mathHint: Count the fourths. How many equal parts?
pages.successMessage: Yes! There are 4 fourths in 1 whole.

pages.menuStory: The party has different foods to share. Each one can be cut into equal parts. What will you share?

pages.question: What is another name for a fourth?
pages.mathContext: Each part is called a fourth. Each part is also called a quarter.
pages.mathHint: Read about fourths. What is another name?
pages.successMessage: Nice! A fourth is also called a quarter.

pages.sentence: I need to share a cookie with my friend. I cut it into 2 equal parts. We each get 1 half. This is a fair share.
pages.mathConcept: Sharing fairly means each person gets an equal part
pages.mathTip: When we share fairly, everyone gets the same amount.

pages.question: I want to share a pizza with 3 friends. How many equal parts do I need?
pages.mathContext: I need to share fairly. I cut into equal parts. Each person gets 1 equal part.
pages.mathHint: Count how many people. You and 3 friends is 4 people total.
pages.successMessage: Great! 4 people need 4 equal parts.

pages.question: Which cut makes halves?
pages.mathContext: A half is 1 of 2 equal parts. When I cut into 2 equal parts, I make halves.
pages.mathHint: Think about halves. How many parts are there?
pages.successMessage: Yes! 2 equal parts make halves.

pages.question: Which cut makes fourths?
pages.mathContext: A fourth is 1 of 4 equal parts. When I cut into 4 equal parts, I make fourths.
pages.mathHint: Think about fourths. How many parts are there?
pages.successMessage: Nice! 4 equal parts make fourths.

pages.question: Are these parts equal?
pages.mathContext: I see a pizza cut into 2 parts. One part is big. One part is small. These parts are not equal.
pages.mathHint: Look at the two parts. Are they the same size?
pages.successMessage: Right! The parts are not equal.
